title: How to Make a Simple Musical Instrument

steps.title: Find a drum base.
steps.content: Find a drum base. You can use an old pot, a bowl, a vase, or a bucket. Choose a deep, sturdy container as your base. Avoid containers made out of glass or other fragile materials. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Get a package of balloons.
steps.content: Get a package of balloons. You'll likely pop a few in the process of making your drum, so it's good to have more than one. Choose large-sized, sturdy balloons. You may want to get a variety of sizes to you can be sure to find one that fits your chosen drum base.

steps.title: Cut the end off a balloon.
steps.content: Cut the end off a balloon. Take a scissors and cut of the end of the balloon right where it becomes narrow. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Stretch the balloon over the base.
steps.content: Stretch the balloon over the base. Use one hand to hold the balloon over one end of the base while you use the other hand to stretch it over the other side. The balloon goes over the opening of the pot, vase, or bucket you're using as the base. [3] X Research source You might want to get a friend to help you hold it it place so it won't snap back. If the balloon you used seems too small or to large for the base, try a different sized balloon.

steps.title: Secure it in place with tape.
steps.content: Secure it in place with tape. Use a heavy-duty piece of packing or duct tape to hold the balloon in place all the way around the rim of your drum base.

steps.title: Play the balloon drum with sticks.
steps.content: Play the balloon drum with sticks. Use chopsticks, pencils, or other long, thin objects to play your drum.

steps.title: Choose a shaker container.
steps.content: Choose a shaker container. You can use an aluminum coffee can, a glass jug with a lid, or cardboard cylinders to make shakers. Wooden containers also work well. Each type of container will end up making a different, unique sound.

steps.title: Pick out something to shake.
steps.content: Pick out something to shake. Any number of small items will make interesting sounds when you shake them. Gather a handful of some or all of the following items: [4] X Research source Beads, either plastic, glass or wooden Dried beans or rice Coins Seeds

steps.title: Put the shaking materials in the container.
steps.content: Put the shaking materials in the container.

steps.title: Seal the container with a lid.
steps.content: Seal the container with a lid.

steps.title: Wrap the container in masking tape.
steps.content: Wrap the container in masking tape. Overlap each loop of tape a bit to make sure the container gets completely covered. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Decorate your shaker.
steps.content: Decorate your shaker. Use paint or and/or other decorating materials to add bright colors and patterns to the shaker.

steps.title: Shake it up.
steps.content: Shake it up. Use the shaker as a percussion instrument by itself or with a band.

steps.title: Get a glass jug or bottle.
steps.content: Get a glass jug or bottle. This works well with a wine bottle, olive oil bottles, large glass jugs, and any other glass container with a skinny neck.

steps.title: Bore a finger-sized hole in the bottom.
steps.content: Bore a finger-sized hole in the bottom. Use a glass cutter to cut a small hole in the bottom of the bottle or jug.

steps.title: Blow across the hole that is already in the top of the jug.
steps.content: Blow across the hole that is already in the top of the jug. Position your lips so that you're blowing horizontally right over the opening. Keep blowing until you get a clear note. This may take a while, so be patient and keep practicing.

steps.title: Cover and uncover the hole on the bottom with your finger.
steps.content: Cover and uncover the hole on the bottom with your finger. Do this as you blow, and experiment with the different sounds it produces.

steps.title: Try tilting your head down and up to make the note sharp or flat.
steps.content: Try tilting your head down and up to make the note sharp or flat.

steps.title: Get five 20 ounce water bottles.
steps.content: Get five 20 ounce water bottles. Choose round bottles with flat bases and wide mouths. You can also do this with jars. Number them 1 through 5. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the bottles with different amounts of water.
steps.content: Fill the bottles with different amounts of water. Add the following amounts to the water bottles: Bottle 1: 19 oz. This will produce an F note. Bottle 2: 13 oz. This will produce a G note. Bottle 3: 11 oz. This will produce an A note. Bottle 4: 8 oz. This will produce a C note. Bottle 5: 6 oz. This will produce a D note.

steps.title: Play the bottles with a metal spoon.
steps.content: Play the bottles with a metal spoon. Tap the spoon against the sides of the bottles to produce notes.

steps.title: Hammer small nails into a paper towel tube.
steps.content: Hammer small nails into a paper towel tube. Hammer them in sideways in random areas around the tube. Hammer in at least 15 or so nails for best effect. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Tape a cover to the bottom of the tube.
steps.content: Tape a cover to the bottom of the tube. Tape a piece of cardboard or another sturdy cover over the bottom of the tube.

steps.title: Add "rain."
steps.content: Add "rain." Pour in some rice, sand, dried beans, beads, popcorn kernels, and other small objects that will make the sound of rain.

steps.title: Cover the top.
steps.content: Cover the top. Add a second cover to the top of the rain stick, and tape it down.

steps.title: Cover the rain stick with wrapping paper.
steps.content: Cover the rain stick with wrapping paper. You could also decorate it with paint or stickers.

steps.title: Play the rain stick.
steps.content: Play the rain stick. Tip it from side to side to hear the sound of falling rain.

steps.title: Get a straw.
steps.content: Get a straw. You can find one at almost any restaurant or you may have some at your house. Small straws (such as coffee stirrers or Capri Sun straws) or straws that bend don't work.

steps.title: Using your teeth, flatten one end of the straw to make a mouthpiece with similar principles as those of a double reed.
steps.content: Using your teeth, flatten one end of the straw to make a mouthpiece with similar principles as those of a double reed. Experiment with it until it makes a noise. If it's easy to blow through and no sound comes out, like a normal straw, try flattening it more. Or you can use your embouchure (lip position) to hold the sides down farther. If it's really hard to blow into, it may be too flat. Blow into the other end to open the "reed" a little.

steps.title: Cut holes into it using a compass and scissors.
steps.content: Cut holes into it using a compass and scissors. Plan out where you want the hole to be, and how big. Keep in mind you'll be covering it with a finger. Poke two holes in the straw using the sharp end of a compass, or something similar. The tiny holes should be at the top and bottom of where you want the hole in the straw. When poking the holes, you should make them as large as possible but be careful that the tool doesn't puncture the other side of the straw or air may leak out. Using scissors, put the tip of each scissor blade into the small holes made by the compass. If the holes are too small for the blades, re-insert the compass and try rotating it a little to make the holes bigger. Make a cut with the scissors to connect the holes. Now that you have a bigger place for the scissors to fit, insert one scissor blade into the line you cut and carefully cut out a circle.

steps.title: Cut as many holes as you'd like.
steps.content: Cut as many holes as you'd like. Don't make too many; remember, you only have so many fingers to play them with! A recommended number is six. If the holes are too high up, they may interfere with the vibrations of the "reed".

steps.title: Blow into the "reed" similarly to a woodwind such as an oboe.
steps.content: Blow into the "reed" similarly to a woodwind such as an oboe. Every straw sounds different. It may even sound just like a clarinet!
